SENT.plain: Marfan syndrome (MFS) is known as an autosomal-dominant connective tissue disorder (MIM 154,700), involving primarily the skeletal, ocular and cardiovascular systems, and caused by mutations in the gene for fibrillin1 (FBN1)
Here, we report on two cousins from a consanguineous family with a homozygous c.1,453C>T FBN1 mutation (p.Arg485Cys) and MFS
All four healthy parents were heterozygous for the c.1,453C>T FBN1 mutation and none fulfilled the Ghent criteria for MFS
This family is the first molecularly confirmed recessive MFS
The demonstration of recessive cases of MFS has obvious implications for genetic counselling as well as for molecular diagnosis
